snippet: The attack at a gathering that showcased caricatures depicting the Prophet Muhammad has prompted Muslims to condemn extremism of any kind while also questioning when free speech becomes hate speech.
abstract: Dallas-area Muslims condemn extremist attack on event in Garland, Tex, that featured caricatures of Prophet Muhammad, but also denounce gathering for stoking bigotry and baiting Muslims by insulting their beliefs; suggest that both attackers and provocateurs are outsiders and have little bearing on their ties to local community, their faith or their American ideals.

byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
byline.contributor: Manny Fernandez reported from Garland, and Laurie Goodstein from New York.

lead_paragraph: The attack at a gathering that showcased caricatures depicting the Prophet Muhammad has prompted Muslims to condemn extremism of any kind while also questioning when free speech becomes hate speech.

headline.main: Shooting Clouds Life as Both Muslim and Texan
headline.print_headline: Shooting Clouds Life as Both Muslim and Texan
